section.title: Introduction to differential equations

introduction.p: We introduce a new category of calculus problems called integrals.

section.subsection:
Applications of derivatives: differential equations
So far we have built methods and skills that allow us to take derivatives of known functions. When we revisit derivatives at the end of the semester, we will see quite a few more applications of derivatives. For now switch perspective and build systematic methods that allow us figure out what original function that a particular derivative comes from.
Methods. To find what original function a derivative comes from, we might
guess the original function
graph the original function (from behaviors encoded by the derivative)
approximate the graph of the original function (Eulers method/tangent line approximations) skipped
integrate to find the original function
A differential equation (often shortened DE) describes the instantaneous rate of change of a measurement.
a pure-time DE is of the form \dfrac{dp}{dt} = f(t) where the instantaneous rate of change of p(t) is measured as a function of time f(t).
an autonomous DE is of the form \dfrac{dp}{dt} = f(p) where the instantaneous rate of change of p(t) is described as a function of the measurement itself f(p).
is, find the function whose derivative is Guess it: Graph it: = e = 2p we will return to autonomous DEs at the end of the chapter -->
Classifying DEs
Identify whether each of the following is a pure-time or autonomous differential equation for the given variable:
\dfrac{dp}{dt} = e^{-t}
\dfrac{dn}{dt} = 2n
\dfrac{dx}{dt} = 2x\Big(1-\dfrac{x}{10}\Big)
\dfrac{dp}{dt} = e^{-t} is a pure-time DE for the variable p
\dfrac{dn}{dt} = 2n is an autonomous DE for the variable n
\dfrac{dx}{dt} = 2x\Big(1-\dfrac{x}{10}\Big) is an autonomous DE for the variable x
Velocity during a walk
Velocity, the instantaneous change in position, of a moving person is given by the pure-time DE \dfrac{dp}{dt} = 1.8, where position p(t) is the quantity being differentiated with respect to time. Find the solution p(t), that satisfies the differential equation.
We have to options: Guess it, Graph it.
Guessing involves thinking of what original function has a derivative of 1.8, based on our experience of taking derivatives. If our derivative is the constant function 1.8, what was the original function p(t)? In other words, "the derivative of what is 1.8?"
Notation for pure-time DEs
In general, we study a pure-time differential equation \dfrac{dF}{dt} = f(t). Solving this pure-time DE for the unknown function F(t) involves finding the function whose derivative is f(t). We want to undo the derivative to find F(t), called the antiderivative of f(t).

Antiderivatives and indefinite integrals
...
An antiderivative of the function f(t) is a function F(t) whose derivative equal to f(t). We say, ""F of t is equal to the integral of f of t with respect to t"", and we write F(t) = \int f(t) \, dt
-->
The equation \dfrac{dp}{dt} = 1.8 has solution p(t) =\int 1.8\,dt = 1.8t + c
What is c?
The set of all antiderivatives of the function f(t) is called the indefinite integral of f and is written \int f(t)\,dt = F(t) + c
Solve pure-time DE \dfrac{dF}{dt} = 2 by computing the indefinite integral.
Solve pure-time DE \dfrac{dF}{dt} = 2t by computing the indefinite integral.
Power rule for integrals
Suppose that f(x) = x^n with n\ne 1, then \int x^n\,dx = \left(\dfrac{1}{n+1}\right)x^{n + 1} + c
Compute \displaystyle \int x^2\,dx.
Compute the indefinite integral of g(x) = x^{0.4}.
Compute \displaystyle \int t^5\,dt.
Compute the indefinite integral of f(t) = \dfrac{1}{t^4}.
Constant product rule for integrals
Suppose that \int f(x)\, dx = F(x) + c, then for any constant a, \int af(x)\,dx = a \int f(x)\,dx=aF(x)+c
Compute \displaystyle \int 12t^5\,dt.
Compute \displaystyle \int \dfrac{3}{t^4}\,dt.
Sum rule for integrals
Suppose that \int f(x)\, dx = F(x) + c and \int g(x)\, dx = G(x) + c, then \int f(x) + g(x)\, dx = \int f(x)\, dx + \int g(x)\, dx = F(x) + G(x) + c
Compute \displaystyle \int 12t^5 + \dfrac{3}{t^4}\,dt.
Consider a seed in a flower in a very tall tree. From an initial height of 14.7 meters, the seed pops straight into the air with an initial velocity of 9.8 \text{meters per second} v(0) = 9.8 \text{m} and an acceleration due to gravity of a(t) = 9.8 \text{m} (in the downward direction). Find the velocity function v(t) and use that to find its position function s(t) of the seed. Then address the following questions
When will the seed land?
What is the velocity of the seed when it smashes into the ground?
